informal_statement: Let $a_1, a_2,\cdots, a_n$ be real constants, $x$ a real variable, and $f(x)=\cos(a_1+x)+\frac{1}{2}\cos(a_2+x)+\frac{1}{4}\cos(a_3+x)+\cdots+\frac{1}{2^{n-1}}\cos(a_n+x).$ Given that $f(x_1)=f(x_2)=0,$ prove that $x_2-x_1=m\pi$ for some integer $m.$
informal_proof:
Because the period of $\cos(x)$ is $2\pi$, the period of $f(x)$ is also $2\pi$.
$f(x_1)=f(x_2)=f(x_1+x_2-x_1)$
We can get $x_2-x_1 = 2k\pi$ for $k\in N^*$. Thus, $x_2-x_1=m\pi$ for some integer $m.$
formal_statement:
theorem imo_1969_p2:
  fixes m n ::real
    and k ::nat
    and a :: "nat \<Rightarrow>real"
    and y :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
  assumes "0 < k"
    and "\<forall> x. y x = (\<Sum> i < k. ((cos (a i + x)) / (2^i)))"
    and "y m = 0"
    and "y n = 0"
  shows "\<exists> t::int. m - n = t * pi"
